sentence.text: ﻿Patient 25 was a 11-year-old Portuguese boy.
Pregnancy and delivery were normal.
His birth weight was 3.6 kg, length 51 cm and head circumference 36 cm.

He was referred to the Genetic Clinic at the age of 8 months because of clinical findings of slightly delayed developmental milestones, cardiac defect (ventricular septum defect), right cryptorchidism and facial dysmorphic features (Figure 2).

At present, he is of low normal intelligence (WISC-R scale: IQ 80) with impairment in expressive language and speech articulation difficulties, emotional behaviour problems with occasional temper tantrums, short stature (132.5 cm; 5th percentile), moderate rhizomelia of upper and lower limbs, short hands with cutaneous syndactyly of fingers, a surgically corrected right-sided cryptorchidism and over-riding scrotum.

Craniofacial findings included relative macrocephaly (OFC 55 cm; 90th percentile), frontal bossing, hypertelorism (inner canthal distance 3.5 cm; >97th percentile – outer canthal distance 11 cm; >97th percentile), down slant of palpebral fissures, short nose with anteverted nostrils, wide philtrum and thin upper lip.
In the past, the chromosomal analysis in peripheral blood lymphocytes had revealed a 46,XY(90%)/47,XYY(10%) mosaic.
Molecular analysis revealed a missense mutation in exon 3 (614 G>T) that causes a change in the residue 205 from Ser to Ile.
The same mutation was found in his mother and in her three sisters, who have mild phenotypical signs (hypertelorism, widow's peak).
Female, 22 years old, the first born to healthy, unrelated Dutch parents.
She has one healthy sibling.
At the age of 1 year she was evaluated because of growth failure, abnormal chest shape and limb shortness.
Skeletal radiographs showed a small, narrow thorax, brachydactyly of the fingers, short and broad diaphyses, and wide metaphyses of the arms and legs, and short iliac bones with spiky protrusions.
There was no history of respiratory difficulties.
At 3 years of age she was admitted because of a respiratory infection.
Blood gas revealed a metabolic acidose, serum creatinine was elevated, urinalysis showed proteinuria and her blood pressure was 200/170 mmHg.
Her renal function deteriorated (serum creatinine 422 μmol/l, ureum 16.8 mmol/l) and at the age of 4 years CAPD was started.
A renal transplant was performed when she was 5 years old and 5 weeks later bilateral nephrectomy was performed because of persistent hypertension.
At the age of 12 years she developed progressive renal failure, as a result of chronic rejection, and she was transplanted for a second time.
Until now, her renal function remained stable.
Ophthalmic examination showed narrow blood vessels without clinical problems.
At the age of 22 years she is living independently and working as a nurse with mildly impaired exercise tolerance.

Physical examination at the age of 22 years showed a height below the third centile, a sitting height/height ratio above the 97th centile, a chest circumference below the third centile, a hand length below the third centile and a foot length below the third centile.
The chest radiograph showed an abnormal position of both ribs and claviculae with a CTR of 0.53 (reference < 0.50; [28]).
Pathological examination of the native kidneys showed that most of the glomeruli were totally sclerotic and the remainder showed capillary collapse.
Periglomular fibrosis, tubular atrophy and dilatation with interstitial lymphocyte infiltration were seen.
﻿Patient 4 (V-9; Fig. 1A) was born in Anjouan Island (Comoros Islands).
This male patient had been referred to Mayotte Island at the age of 7 years.
His past medical history and birth parameters were unknown.
He presented craniosynostosis and a kyphoscoliosis measured at 100°.
He was hospitalized at 12 years of age.
His weight was 44 kg (75th centile) and his height was 130 cm (3rd centile).
He presented severe craniosynostosis with a trilobular cloverleaf-shaped skull and marked scaphocephaly.
Facial features included midface hypoplasia, a flat nasal bridge, epicanthic folds, hypertelorism, and low-set ears (Fig. 2A).
There were bilateral camptodactyly of the fourth and fifth fingers, and bilateral ulnar deviation of third, fourth, and fifth fingers (Fig. 2A).
He had a bilateral genu valgum and enlarged distal femoral and proximal tibial metaphyses, left hip dislocation, and a major kyphoscoliosis (Fig. 2C).
The testes were not palpable.
Walking was possible, but he most often used a wheelchair.
Mental development was normal.
Skull X-ray demonstrated synostosis of the coronal and sagittal sutures.

Radiographs of the hands revealed bilateral agenesis of the middle phalanges of the second fingers, bilateral hypoplastic middle phalanges of the third, fourth, and fifth fingers, and enlarged thumbs (Fig. 2B).

annotation.text: middle phalanges of the second fingers

sentence.text: Radiographs of feet showed bilateral agenesis of the middle phalanges of the second to the fifth toes, a broad first metatarsal bone, broad phalanges of the halluces, a synostosis of the first tarsometatarsal joint, and an extra epiphyseal bone lying to the distal side of the first metatarsal bone (Fig. 2B).

annotation.text: middle phalanges of the second to the fifth toes
middle phalanges of the second to the fifth toes
middle phalanges of the second to the fifth toes
middle phalanges of the second to the fifth toes

sentence.text: Radiographs of the spine showed severe kyphoscoliosis measured at 130° (Fig. 2C).
Routine laboratory blood tests and cytogenetic study of peripheral lymphocytes were normal.
Extra digits were removed and surgical reduction of the scoliosis was performed.
Cranioplasty was not performed because of delayed neurosurgical consultation, absence of hydrocephaly, and refusal of specialized care by the family.
﻿Case 3 is a male in his 20s born to Swiss unrelated parents.
He was born by caesarean section at term with a weight of 2570 g and a length of 45 cm.

Postaxial polydactyly of the hands, preaxial polydactyly of the feet, and facial dysmorphism such as a bulging forehead with receding hair line, bilateral epicanthus, mild down-slant of narrow palpebral fissures, hypertelorism, scarce upper eyelashes and absent lower eyelashes, convergent strabismus and bilateral pits of the ear lobes were noted.

Moreover, he had pseudarthrosis of the right clavicle, hypospadias, bilateral inguinal hernias, right-sided cryptorchidism, widely spaced nipples, a large fontanel (6×6 cm), bifid uvula, and a short neck.
The diagnosis of ACLS was proposed.

Cerebral ultrasound investigations revealed enlarged lateral ventricles and a suspicion of corpus callosum hypoplasia, which was said to have been confirmed by Computed Tomography (CT) imaging during childhood.
At the age of 4 months, measurements were 61 cm length (3rd centile), 6020 g weight (10th centile), 42.5 cm HC (25th centile), and a 7×8 cm open fontanel.
Already at this time, a developmental delay of 2 months was noted and a hypoplastic optic nerve disc was mentioned.
At the age of 7 years, when the boy was given to foster parents, he could hardly walk, had hardly any speech, and very low vision.
At the age of 14 years, he underwent normal puberty.
Since the age of 15 years he had bladder control both day and night and no longer needed diapers (nappies).
At the age of 18 years he still had limited beard growth and scarce axillary hair.
It was said that he had tunnel vision and that an electroretinogram at the age of 5.75 years had shown abnormal results, arguing for a retinopathy.
His height was reported to be 185 cm (90th centile), weight 7.2 kg (75–90th centile), and HC 58 cm (75–90th centile).
Ear length was asymmetric with 7 cm on the left side and 6.3 cm on the right side.
Ears were low set and posteriorly rotated, with an underfolded apical helix and hypoplastic lobes.
The forehead was high and broad, palpebral fissures were narrow with mild epicanthal folds and mild down-slant.
The nasal bridge was broad, and the philtrum short and prominent.
Lips were full and everted with a median groove in the upper lip, and the tongue was large.
The neck was short with a low hair line and a flat occiput.
Fingers were tapering with limited distal interphalangeal joint mobility of the fifth fingers.
He was said to occasionally have temper tantrums with destructiveness.

At the age of 21 years he was able to walk freely, but in small steps with flexion contracture of knees up to 1 km, to ride a tandem bike, to swim, to get himself dressed apart from closing zippers and putting on socks, and to cut food.
Due to calcaneous-valgus deformity, he needed ortheses.
He had a limited vision with very high myopia, nystagmus, and nasal, inarticulate speech.
He had a good memory, was able to count to 30 and to communicate well, but was unable to read or write.
He had become obese with a height of 183 cm (>75th centile) and weight of 94.5 kg (>97th centile).

We identified two KIF7 heterozygous mutations: a substitution at the acceptor splice site of intron 12 c.2593-3C>G inherited from the father, and a nonsense mutation in exon 15 (c.3001C>T, p.Gln1001X) inherited from his mother.

The c.2593-3C>G variation is absent from SNP databases and 1000 genomes, and its in silico analysis by Human Splicing Finder (see URLs) shows a reduced score of intron 12 acceptor splice site from 86 to 74, while it is abolished with NNSPLICE 0.9 (see URLs).
The sister of the mother also had a daughter with polydactyly and a clinical diagnosis of acrocallosal or Mohr syndrome, but was not interested in further investigations.
Female, first examined in the outpatient clinic at 7 years old due to short stature with brachydactyly.
At that age, she complained that she could not ride a bike because her hands were so small that she could not use the bike brake to stop it.
She is the only daughter of non-consanguineous parents.
Pregnancy was uneventful until the 28th week, when oligohydramnios and IUGR were detected.
She was born by C-section at 37 weeks with a birth weight = 1,630 g (−4 SD); birth length = 41 cm (−4.2 SD); and head circumference (OFC) = 32 cm (−1 SD).
She had good neuropsychomotor development.
Her physical examination showed mild disproportionate short stature with a height of 114.5 cm (−3 SD) due to very small hands (total hand length 10.5 cm and middle finger length 4.2 cm, both −2 SD).

There was a round face with hypoplasia of the middle of the face, a short bulbous nose, and a slightly prominent chin, as well as small feet with a wide hallux and shortening of the digits, especially from the third to the fifth toes (Figure 3).

annotation.text: hypoplasia of the middle of the face

sentence.text: Serum calcium phosphorus and alkaline phosphatase were normal, however, PTH level was elevated (99.0 pg/ml [reference value = 15–65 pg/ml]).
Endocrinological evaluation diagnosed pseudohypoparathyroidism and hypothyroidism.
At 11 years old, she had avascular necrosis of the right femur head.
Menarche occurred at the age of 13 years.
In her last evaluation, at 14 years old, she seemed a smart girl and was obese (body mass index [BMI] = 31.7).
Her measurement showed weight = 65.750 kg (+2 SD), height = 144 cm (−2.4 SD), OFC = 56.8 cm (+2 SD).

Radiological examination showed advanced carpal maturation and accentuated brachydactyly in hands and feet with involvement of all the long bones, but mainly of the metacarpal and metatarsal bones with cone-shaped epiphyses in hands.
Hypoplasia of the iliac wings, and slight enlargement of the distal metaphysis of the femur, reminiscent of Erlenmeyer shape, were also observed.

annotation.text: enlargement of the distal metaphysis of the femur

sentence.text: Epiphyseal involvement was also observed in femoral heads and the medial portion of the tibial epiphysis; in both regions, some hypoplasia was observed (Figure 3).
Although she had initially been diagnosed as having Acrodysostosis, her endocrinological disturbance led us also to consider Albright dysplasia as a real diagnostic possibility.
The targeted NGS showed a heterozygous pathogenic variant in exon 11 of PRKAR1A gene—c.1102C > T (p.Arg368*), confirming the initial diagnosis of acrodysostosis.
The proband (P1) is a 12-year-old girl born to non-consanguineous Italian couple, which was addressed to our Center in the suspicion of an overgrowth syndrome.
Pregnancy was uneventful, except for dysplastic multicystic right kidney and femur length at the upper limits at morphology scan.
She was born at 40 weeks of gestation; birth weight was 3.250 kg (50–75th centile) and length 52 cm (50th centile).
Length became >97th centile since the first months of life, and the right dysplastic kidney atrophied over time.
Thyroid and pelvic US scan were normal, whereas carpal x-ray revealed a bone age 4 years older than chronological age.
In addition, spine x-ray revealed left-convex lumbar rotoscoliosis with moderate right-convex compensatory curvature.
She also had valgus knees and flat feet.
At the age of 10 years, bilateral pantonal sensorineural hearing loss was diagnosed.
Dental examination revealed peg-shaped incisors.

At 12 years of age, she weighed 74.8 kg (+2.04 SD), height was 185.5 cm (+4.35 SD), and she had relative microcephaly, since occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) was 52.2 cm (−0.95 SD); body mass index (BMI) was 21.7 (+0.44 SD), arm-span was 182 cm with normal arm span/height ratio (0.98).
Her intellectual and social development was normal.
Mild dysmorphic features include high frontal hairline, slight asymmetric face, deeply set eyes, slight prognathism, small ears, bifid uvula and peg-shaped incisors.

She had long and thin fingers, prominent phalanx epiphyses, camptodactyly of fingers and toes, first and second fingers clinodactyly on the left hand and of second and third fingers on the right hand.
She also had clinodactyly and proximal placement of the fifth toes bilaterally (Figure 1).

annotation.text: proximal placement of the fifth toes

sentence.text: She showed mild joint hyperextensibility with Beighton score of 5/9 (Positive Beighton score ≥5).
Skin examination revealed no striae distensae, bruising, atrophic scars or pigmentation disorders.
